entities.name: Bathing
entities.description: Bathe your dog once or twice each year. If you bathe your dog more frequently, you could remove the natural oils which protect its skin. Use tear-free shampoo and work it into your dog’s skin folds when bathing. Lather the shampoo and let it sit for a minute or two before rinsing.

entities.name: Feeding Puppy
entities.description: Young bulldogs need several small meals throughout the day. Your puppy may need to eat up to four times a day. Puppies generally need about 20-70 calories per pound of body weight. Don’t just leave food out for your puppy. Even though it needs to eat more frequently than an adult bulldog, it is still susceptible to overeating. Removing bowls of food after your puppy has finished will keep it healthy.

entities.name: Diet Change
entities.description: Do not change your bulldog’s diet until it is at least three to four months old. After obtaining your bulldog (of any age), wait at least two weeks before changing its diet. After two weeks, gradually introduce new foods into its diet and alternate new foods with its standard diet. Monitor your dog’s reaction. If it has soft or excessive stool, switch back to the old diet, then try again later to introduce a different new food after two more weeks.

entities.name: Feeding Adult
entities.description: The caloric needs of your bulldog will depend on its age and activity level. After about 18 months, your bulldog should be treated nutritionally as an adult. Older dogs usually need about 937 calories per day. Typical adult bulldogs need around 1,145 calories each day. A very active English bulldog could need as much as 1,300 calories in a day. While puppies require four meals each day, an adult will usually eat just twice each day.

entities.name: Nutritious Diet
entities.description: Your bulldog should receive a healthy balance of protein, carbs, fats, vitamins, and minerals. There are many commercial dog foods available which can satisfy your dog, and some dog foods that are designed specifically for bulldogs. Look for a dog food that is nutritious and ask your vet if you have specific concerns about what your dog is eating. Avoid dog foods that are predominately carbs like corn and sugar. Dog foods that include high protein contents and slowly-digestible carbs like sweet potatoes and barley are good choices.

entities.name: Healthy Weight
entities.description: If your bulldog is overweight, it may have heart, hip, and breathing problems later in life. Obesity also increases your dog’s chances of developing cancer by as much as 20%. You can keep its weight down by feeding it only moderate meals and providing opportunities for regular light exercise like going for walks at the park, or romps at the local dog park.

entities.name: Diet Variety
entities.description: While table scraps can often upset a bulldog’s tummy, there are many ways to include new foods and make fun changes to your dog’s meals. For instance, your bulldog might enjoy apple cinnamon drops.

entities.name: Toxic Foods
entities.description: There are many foods that humans find yummy but are toxic to bulldogs. For instance, grapes, raisins, beer, raw bread dough, chocolate or anything caffeinated, garlic, and onions should never be consumed by dogs. English bulldogs, like all dogs, should especially avoid alcohol, grapes, and raisins. Foods that are nonfatal but may irritate your bulldog include peas, beans, milk, and fatty or spicy foods.

entities.name: English Bulldog Eye Health
entities.description: English Bulldogs can develop many eye problems. Daily monitoring of the eyes is necessary. Heavy crusty layer and excessively runny eyes are signs of potential issues. Conditions like entropion (eyelids rolling inward) and ectropion (eyelids sagging or rolling down) can occur. Any unusual eye problems should be immediately addressed by a vet.

entities.name: Beta-carotene
entities.description: Beta carotene strengthens the eyes. Foods high in beta-carotene are hard to find in dog food. However, adding small portions of foods high in beta carotene to your dog’s diet can keep its eyes healthy. Sweet potatoes and carrots are good sources of beta carotene.

entities.name: Cherry Eye
entities.description: Cherry eye is a common problem in English bulldogs. The red swelling is a tear gland that has prolapsed forward. It should be kept well lubricated to prevent secondary infections. While it does not usually cause pain for your dog immediately, if it gets infected, it may. Treatment usually involves a surgical procedure or keeping the gland lubricated.

entities.name: English Bulldog Exercise
entities.description: English bulldogs are low-energy animals but require exercise to stay healthy and engaged. Short walks around the block and indoor play are recommended. Exercise also provides bonding time for the owner and the dog.

entities.name: English Bulldog Training
entities.description: Training an English bulldog can be difficult. Start slowly and practice a trick for a short time each day. Patience is required during the training process.

entities.name: English Bulldog Overwork
entities.description: English bulldogs have lower energy levels than other dogs. They have a hard time running long distances or engaging in vigorous exercise. Bulldogs have flattened noses and find it more difficult to breathe. They are prone to heat stroke in hot weather. Gentle walks in the cooler parts of the day, sticking to the shade, and providing them with plenty of water are recommended.

entities.name: Neuter or Spay
entities.description: Neutering or spaying a dog makes them less aggressive and easier to control. It also has many other positive benefits, such as lower licensing fees, reduced chance for prostrate disorders, and reduced chance for testicular cancer.

entities.name: English Bulldog Heat Sensitivity
entities.description: English bulldogs have weak respiratory systems and have even greater difficulty breathing in hot, humid weather. During the hot season, keep your dog in air-conditioning. Monitor your dog when it plays outside on hot days to ensure it doesn’t tire itself out. Do not leave your dog in a hot house or car.

entities.name: English Bulldog Attention and Love
entities.description: Bulldogs thrive off attention from their owners. Giving them lots of attention and love helps form a bond that will last as long as your Bulldog lives.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog with a lovable appearance and gentle manners. Keeping it healthy is a challenge due to its many inborn physical deficiencies.

entities.name: Skin Folds
entities.description: English bulldogs’ skin is layered in folds, which is susceptible to diseases like yeast intertrigo, a condition which leads to itchy rashes on the skin.

entities.name: Anti-fungal Wipe
entities.description: Used to clean the skin folds of an English Bulldog. It should be nontoxic and preferably contain natural ingredients like cucumber and chamomile.

entities.name: Skin Irritation
entities.description: A condition that can occur in English Bulldogs due to their skin folds. Signs include constant scratching, rubbing, or biting, nasty odors, and brown discharge from the skin folds.

entities.name: Vet
entities.description: A professional who can help with severe skin problems in English Bulldogs, such as infected, itching, and dry skin.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog that requires specific care and feeding routines.

entities.name: Puppy Feeding
entities.description: Young bulldogs need several small meals throughout the day, up to four times a day. Puppies generally need about 20-70 calories per pound of body weight.

entities.name: Diet Change
entities.description: Do not change your bulldog’s diet until it is at least three to four months old. After obtaining your bulldog, wait at least two weeks before changing its diet.

entities.name: Adult Bulldog Feeding
entities.description: The caloric needs of your bulldog will depend on its age and activity level. After about 18 months, your bulldog should be treated nutritionally as an adult. Older dogs usually need about 937 calories per day. Typical adult bulldogs need around 1,145 calories each day.

entities.name: Nutritious Diet
entities.description: Your bulldog should receive a healthy balance of protein, carbs, fats, vitamins, and minerals. Avoid dog foods that are predominately carbs like corn and sugar.

entities.name: Healthy Weight
entities.description: If your bulldog is overweight, it may have heart, hip, and breathing problems later in life. Obesity also increases your dog’s chances of developing cancer by as much as 20%.

entities.name: Diet Variety
entities.description: While table scraps can often upset a bulldog’s tummy, there are many ways to include new foods and make fun changes to your dog’s meals.

entities.name: Toxic Foods
entities.description: There are many foods that humans find yummy but are toxic to bulldogs. For instance, grapes, raisins, beer, raw bread dough, chocolate or anything caffeinated, garlic, and onions should never be consumed by dogs.

entities.name: Eye Health
entities.description: Refers to the overall health and condition of a dog's eyes. Regular checks are necessary to identify any unusual changes or symptoms.

entities.name: Entropion
entities.description: A condition where the dog's eyelids roll inward, leading to tearing, squinting, and ulcers in the eye.

entities.name: Ectropion
entities.description: A condition where the dog's eyelids sag or appear to be rolling down, leading to signs of dry eyes and unusual frequency of blinking.

entities.name: Cherry Eye
entities.description: A common problem in English bulldogs where the red swelling is a tear gland that has prolapsed forward. It should be kept well lubricated to prevent secondary infections.

entities.name: Beta-carotene
entities.description: A nutrient that strengthens the eyes. Foods high in beta-carotene, such as sweet potatoes and carrots, can be added to the dog's diet to keep its eyes healthy.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog with a lovable appearance and gentle manners. It has many inborn physical deficiencies, making its health a challenge to maintain.

entities.name: Skin Folds
entities.description: Layered skin folds in English Bulldogs that are susceptible to diseases like yeast intertrigo, leading to itchy rashes on the skin.

entities.name: Anti-fungal Wipe
entities.description: A nontoxic wipe used to clean the skin folds of an English Bulldog. It should contain natural ingredients like cucumber and chamomile and be free of harmful chemicals and additives.

entities.name: Skin Irritation
entities.description: A condition that can occur in English Bulldogs due to issues with their skin folds. Signs include constant scratching, rubbing, biting, nasty odors, and brown discharge from the skin folds.

entities.name: Vet
entities.description: A professional who is trained to deal with severe problems like infected, itching, and dry skin in dogs, including English Bulldogs.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog that requires specific care and feeding routines.

entities.name: Puppy Feeding
entities.description: Young bulldogs need several small meals throughout the day, up to four times a day. Puppies generally need about 20-70 calories per pound of body weight.

entities.name: Adult Bulldog Feeding
entities.description: The caloric needs of your bulldog will depend on its age and activity level. After about 18 months, your bulldog should be treated nutritionally as an adult. Older dogs usually need about 937 calories per day. Typical adult bulldogs need around 1,145 calories each day. A very active English bulldog could need as much as 1,300 calories in a day.

entities.name: Diet Variety
entities.description: There are many ways to include new foods and make fun changes to your dog’s meals. For instance, your bulldog might enjoy apple cinnamon drops.

entities.name: Toxic Foods
entities.description: There are many foods that humans find yummy but are toxic to bulldogs. For instance, grapes, raisins, beer, raw bread dough, chocolate or anything caffeinated, garlic, and onions should never be consumed by dogs.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog with a lovable appearance and gentle manners. It has many inborn physical deficiencies, making its health a challenge to maintain.

entities.name: Skin Folds
entities.description: Layered skin folds in English Bulldogs that are susceptible to diseases like yeast intertrigo, leading to itchy rashes on the skin.

entities.name: Anti-fungal Wipe
entities.description: A nontoxic wipe used to clean the skin folds of an English Bulldog. It should contain natural ingredients like cucumber and chamomile and should be free from harmful chemicals and additives.

entities.name: Skin Irritation
entities.description: A condition that can occur in English Bulldogs due to issues with their skin folds. Signs include constant scratching, rubbing, or biting, nasty odors, and a brown discharge from the skin folds.

entities.name: Vet
entities.description: A professional who is trained to deal with severe problems like infected, itching, and dry skin in dogs, including English Bulldogs.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: A breed of dog known for its distinctive wrinkled face and pushed-in nose. They have lower energy levels than other dogs and have weak respiratory systems.

entities.name: Exercise
entities.description: English bulldogs require light exercise to stay healthy and engaged. This can include short walks, playing with a ball, or tug of war.

entities.name: Training
entities.description: Training an English bulldog can be difficult and requires patience. They may not learn tricks as fast as other dogs.

entities.name: Heat
entities.description: English bulldogs have difficulty breathing in hot, humid weather. They should be kept in air-conditioning during hot seasons and monitored when playing outside on hot days.

entities.name: Neutering/Spaying
entities.description: Neutering or spaying an English bulldog can make them less aggressive and easier to control. It also has other benefits such as lower licensing fees and reduced chance for prostrate disorders and testicular cancer.

entities.name: Attention and Love
entities.description: English bulldogs thrive off attention from their owners. Giving them attention and love helps form a strong bond.

relationships.description: After bathing, the next step in caring for an English Bulldog is feeding, especially for puppies.
After feeding the puppy, the diet of the bulldog should be changed slowly as it grows.
After the diet change, the feeding pattern changes as the bulldog matures.
After establishing the feeding pattern, the focus should be on providing a nutritious diet.
Maintaining a nutritious diet helps in keeping the bulldog within a healthy weight.
While maintaining a healthy weight, variety can be introduced in the diet.
While introducing variety in the diet, care should be taken to avoid toxic foods.
Feeding your dog foods high in beta-carotene can help keep its eyes healthy.
English Bulldogs can develop a condition known as Cherry Eye.
Providing light exercise for your dog can prevent overwork and related health issues.
Training an English bulldog can be easier after the dog is neutered or spayed.
Overworking an English bulldog, especially in hot weather, can lead to heat stroke due to their heat sensitivity.
Giving your English bulldog lots of attention and love can facilitate the training process.
English Bulldogs have skin folds which can lead to health issues.
The skin folds of an English Bulldog should be cleaned daily with an anti-fungal wipe to prevent diseases.
English Bulldogs can have skin irritation due to their skin folds.
Severe skin irritation in English Bulldogs can be treated by a vet.
English Bulldog puppies require several small meals throughout the day.
English Bulldogs require a gradual change in diet after they are three to four months old.
Adult English Bulldogs require specific caloric intake based on their age and activity level.
English Bulldogs require a balanced and nutritious diet.
English Bulldogs should maintain a healthy weight to avoid health problems.
English Bulldogs can have a variety in their diet, but certain foods can upset their stomach.
English Bulldogs should avoid certain foods that are toxic to them.
If a dog's eyelids are rolling inward, it might have entropion.
If a dog's eyelids are sagging or appear to be rolling down, it might have ectropion.
Cherry eye is a common problem in English bulldogs.
Beta carotene strengthens the eyes. Foods high in beta-carotene can keep a dog's eyes healthy.
English Bulldogs have a characteristic feature of layered skin folds.
The skin folds of an English Bulldog should be cleaned daily with an anti-fungal wipe to prevent diseases like yeast intertrigo.
English Bulldogs can have skin irritation due to issues with their skin folds.
Skin irritation in English Bulldogs that cannot be managed by the owner should be treated by a vet.
English Bulldog puppies require several small meals throughout the day.
Adult English Bulldogs require specific caloric intake based on their age and activity level.
English Bulldogs can benefit from a variety in their diet, such as apple cinnamon drops.
English Bulldogs should avoid certain foods that are toxic to them, such as grapes, raisins, beer, raw bread dough, chocolate or anything caffeinated, garlic, and onions.

The skin folds of an English Bulldog should be cleaned daily with an anti-fungal wipe to prevent diseases like yeast intertrigo.
English Bulldogs can have skin irritation due to issues with their skin folds.
Skin irritation in English Bulldogs that cannot be managed by the owner should be treated by a vet.
English bulldogs require light exercise to stay healthy and engaged.
Training an English bulldog can be difficult and requires patience.
English bulldogs have difficulty breathing in hot, humid weather.
Neutering or spaying an English bulldog can make them less aggressive and easier to control.
English bulldogs thrive off attention from their owners.
